app_footer: Inspired by the Anglican Three-Legged Stool: Scripture, Tradition, and Reason.

questions.text: The authority of the Church is primarily derived from...

options.text: Apostolic succession and sacred tradition.
The individual's conscience and reason.
The inerrant Word of God in Scripture.
A balance of Scripture, Tradition, and Reason.
Scripture as the highest authority, interpreted with the guidance of tradition and reason.
The consensus of the worshipping community, as it seeks the Holy Spirit's guidance.

questions.text: The Eucharist is best understood as...

options.text: The Real Presence of Christ's Body and Blood.
A communal meal symbolizing fellowship and inclusion.
A memorial of Christ's atoning sacrifice.
A spiritual presence, a mystery to be embraced.
A true spiritual presence of Christ, received by faith (a 'receptionist' view).
A foretaste of the heavenly banquet, a sign of future hope.
Elaborate ritual, incense, and vestments ('smells and bells').
Innovative, contemporary language and flexible forms.
A simple, Scripture-focused service like Morning Prayer.
The traditional language and structure of the Book of Common Prayer.
A dignified liturgy that is accessible and understandable to newcomers.
A quiet, contemplative service with space for silence and personal reflection (e.g., Taizé style).
Intercessors in heaven to be venerated and asked for prayer.
Inspiring historical figures, but not objects of devotion.
A concept that distracts from the sole mediatorship of Christ.
Exemplars of faith whose lives we should emulate.
Part of the 'great cloud of witnesses' who inspire us and with whom we are in communion.
Our ancestors in faith, whose stories are part of our collective family memory.
Faith, participation in the sacraments, and good works.
Living a just life and working for social transformation.
Faith alone (Sola Fide) in Jesus Christ.
A journey of faith, the details of which are a mystery.
Faith in Christ, which is expressed and made real through a life of love and good works.
A process of 'theosis' or deification, becoming partakers of the divine nature through grace.
With guidance from Church tradition and the Magisterium.
Using modern critical methods and acknowledging its human elements.
Literally, as the infallible and direct word of God.
As God's word, best understood through prayer, scholarship, and community discussion.
Prayerfully by the individual, guided by the Holy Spirit.
As a grand, overarching narrative of God's relationship with creation, to be entered into imaginatively.

questions.text: On matters of social ethics, the Church should...

options.text: Uphold timeless moral truths as revealed in tradition.
Adapt its teachings in light of new scientific and social understanding.
Adhere strictly to moral commands explicitly found in the Bible.
Foster dialogue and allow for a diversity of opinions.
Apply core Christian principles of love and justice to contemporary issues, even if that leads to new conclusions.
Be based on natural law and universal moral reasoning, accessible to all people of goodwill.
To govern the church as successors to the Apostles.
An administrative function that can be reformed or re-imagined.
A historical structure, but not essential for a valid church.
To provide pastoral oversight and maintain unity.
To be a sign of unity and historical continuity, serving as chief pastors and teachers.
To be servants of the servants of God, primarily defined by their pastoral care and willingness to suffer for the flock.

questions.text: Art and beauty in church architecture...

options.text: Are essential for glorifying God and inspiring worship.
Should reflect the culture and creativity of the local community.
Can be a potential source of idolatry and should be minimal.
Are nice but secondary to the function of the space.
Should be used to edify the faithful and teach the faith, but with simplicity to avoid distraction.
Should be sustainable, using natural materials and light, to reflect God's creation and our call to stewardship.
May hold elements of truth, but the fullness of truth resides in the Church.
Are valid paths to the divine and should be engaged with openly.
Are false paths; salvation is only through Jesus.
Are opportunities for interfaith dialogue and mutual learning.
God can work outside the visible Church, but Christ is the unique and full revelation of God.
People of other faiths can be saved through Christ, even if they don't know him by name ('anonymous Christians').

questions.text: My prayer life is centered on...

options.text: The Daily Office, rosary, or other formal devotions.
Meditation, mindfulness, or engagement with social justice work.
Extemporaneous prayer and personal Bible study.
The structured prayers of the Book of Common Prayer.
A mix of liturgical prayer (like the Daily Office) and personal, spontaneous prayer.
Embodied practices like walking a labyrinth, pilgrimage, or using prayer beads.
Adherence to the faith of the one, holy, catholic and apostolic Church.
Universal, inclusive, and embracing of all humanity.
A term to be cautious of due to its association with Rome.
A reference to the ancient, undivided Church.
The universal church, which is 'reformed' and stands in continuity with the apostles, distinct from the Roman communion.
A commitment to the poor and marginalized, reflecting God's universal love for all.
A vital sacrament for the forgiveness of sins, ideally with a priest.
A therapeutic practice, but not a requirement for forgiveness.
Handled directly between the individual and God.
Meaningfully done through the general confession in corporate worship.
Sufficient in the general confession, but private confession is a valuable resource when needed.
A corporate practice where the community confesses its role in systemic sin and seeks reconciliation.

questions.text: The primary mission of the Church is...

options.text: To administer the sacraments and bring people into the apostolic faith.
To be a voice for the marginalized and challenge unjust systems.
To preach the Gospel and evangelize the world for personal conversion.
To worship God and build a loving community.
To proclaim the Good News, teach, respond to need, transform society, and safeguard creation (Five Marks of Mission).
To build the 'Beloved Community'—a society based on justice, equal opportunity, and love of one's fellow human beings.

questions.text: When considering the ordination of women, I believe...

options.text: It is contrary to apostolic tradition and Scripture.
It is a matter of justice and reflects the equality of all in Christ.
It is permissible if a church body feels led by the Spirit, but not mandated.
It is a valid development of tradition, though I respect differing views.
While tradition is male-only, the Spirit may be doing a new thing in our time.
A secondary issue that has unfortunately divided the church; unity is more important than a final decision.

questions.text: Clerical vestments for the Eucharist should ideally consist of...

options.text: The full works: amice, alb, girdle, maniple, stole, and chasuble. They signify the sacredness of the office.
Vestments are optional and can be adapted to the local culture, or dispensed with, to foster a sense of inclusion.
No vestments are necessary beyond what is required for decency; they can create a barrier between clergy and laity.
A simple alb and stole is sufficient. It is ancient, ecumenical, and avoids excessive ritualism.
The traditional Anglican Choir Habit: a cassock, surplice, and a tippet or stole. It is dignified and historically grounded.
A simple business suit or clerical collar with street clothes. The goal is to be approachable and professional.
